body: As the snow deepened Sunday and Monday, roughly 100 front-line 911 operators in Downtown Brooklyn fielded tens of thousands of calls, struggling to sort the true emergencies from an ocean of concerns about stranded cars, twisted ankles and people simply stuck in their homes. The result was frayed nerves and growing exhaustion, as call after call
title: 'It Was Hell': Weary Dispatchers Describe Flood of 911 Calls During Storm

body: NEW YEAR'S EVE, 2008. My boyfriend and I are at our local bar in Brooklyn. He is drinking a pint of Smithwick's, and I am nursing a Jameson, neat. I take small sips, and the bartender eyes me. Cheap date, I am. We are exhausted from the holidays, so the only celebration we can muster is the two-block walk to Shenanigans on Caton Avenue, where a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | KENSINGTON; Where the Beers And the Jeers Flow Freely

body: KENNY--Dorothy, passed away on Thursday December 16. She is survived and beloved by her nieces and nephews Nicola Kenny of Ossining NY, Erica Kenny of Boston MA, Russell Kenny of Greenwich CT, Terence and Dorothy O'Brien of Madison NJ, Christopher O'Brien of Brooklyn NY, and many other friends and relatives. Ms. Kenny was a lifelong resident of the
title: Paid Notice: Deaths KENNY, DOROTHY

body: AMONG the heirloom antiques that Bronson Van Wyck, the Manhattan party planner, keeps in his cavernous Flatiron district apartment is a giant map of England from the 1930s, on which each social engagement of King George VI was meticulously plotted. ''This was found rolled up in a closet in Princess Margaret's apartment at Kensington Palace after
title: UP CLOSE; A-List Parties: More Taste, Less Flash

body: Philip Carlo, who produced novels and nonfiction accounts of serial killers and hit men before writing about his own struggles with disease, died on Nov. 8 in Manhattan. He was 61. The cause was a combination of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, and cancer, said his wife, Laura Garofalo-Carlo. A stay at Bellevue
title: Philip Carlo, 61;Wrote About Crime Figures

body: FROM the window of his waterfront office in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, Sufjan Stevens can see traffic creeping along Manhattan's eastern edge, just across the river. He can see the party boats and barges float by, joined occasionally by groups of kayakers. And he can see the workers at the Con Edison power plant across from his building. It
title: Mr. Strummy-Strum Tries a Synth Sound

author: Arthur Lubow is a contributing writer to the magazine.
body: IN A BLUSTERY ECONOMIC climate, with waves of populist resentment thundering outside the thickest paneled doors, what do rich people want in a home? Is it their wish to be exposed in glass-and-steel boxes? Will they opt for precarious-seeming triumphs of cantilevered engineering? Or are they, perhaps, looking for something else? Last winter, I went
title: The Traditionalist

body: THREE years ago, when Lisa Rosenberg and Thomas Kitts met at a neighborhood bar, they lived half a mile apart in Brooklyn, each renting a three-bedroom apartment, each divorced and the parent of two teenagers, each paying around $2,000 a month. They shared a love of music. One thing led to another and, ''knowing we would be together for the long
title: THE HUNT; A Tall Order for a Large Family

body: HOW could he possibly relinquish the lease on a $714 rent-stabilized one-bedroom? Everyone told Gary Parker he was crazy. But he was the one living the reality behind the cheap rent. His railroad apartment in South Park Slope, Brooklyn, was noisy, dark and badly maintained. He longed for a better quality of life. Mr. Parker, who grew up near
title: THE HUNT; Because Dirt-Cheap Has Its Downsides

body: The doorways inside 30 Ocean Parkway, an Art Deco building in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, are studded with mezuzas of all sizes and styles: plastic, pewter, simple, gaudy, elegant. The people behind those doors are an assortment, too: Catholics, Baptists, Episcopalians, Buddhists, atheists and even a few observing the High Holy Days this week. ''I
title: On Doorways, A Jewish Custom Inherited by Gentiles

body: TWENTY years ago, when Fifth Avenue in Park Slope could still be called marginal in the pages of The New York Times, Michael Ayoub opened Cucina there, on the corner of Carroll Street. The restaurant was an elegantly casual Italian trattoria that managed to charm both a burgeoning population of young brownstoners with jobs in Manhattan and the
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; Who Needs the Gastrotourists?

body: Since Evelyn Kozak was born on the Lower East Side on Aug. 14, 1899, she has outlived two husbands and survived the Spanish flu and two strokes. She ran a boardinghouse in Miami until she was 90 and avidly played Scrabble until she was 95. In January, she moved in with a granddaughter -- and eight great-grandchildren under 13 -- in the Kensington
title: Searching for New York's Oldest, and Finding Them

body: IN a city that's ever on the go, it's a happy circumstance that there are so many decent sandwich shops. If inclined to, you can eat your meals three times a day between slices of bread, and in that manner dine lavishly. It's not just the same old sandwich suspects, either. Take breakfast, for instance, at the Prospect Lefferts Garden location of
title: $25 AND UNDER; Half a Loaf Is Better When Stuffed

body: WHEN Jen Rosenbaum told her colleagues that she was determined to find an apartment for just $1,200 to $1,500 a month, they laughed. Clearly, she was on a fool's errand. ''My co-workers said it is not going to happen, you are insane,'' she said. But Miss Rosenbaum was certain she could easily find a great cheap apartment. After all, she had heard
title: THE HUNT; An Optimist Goes After the Near-Impossible

body: SOME arrived as early as 1987, others as recently as this year. Many came by way of Fort Wayne, Ind., where they originally landed as refugees but could not find enough work. Now, more than 300 immigrants from the war-torn Darfur region of Sudan live in Kensington, Brooklyn, according to the leaders of the Darfur People's Association of New York, a
title: From Darfur To a Corner Of Brooklyn

body: THE journey that took Filipp and Raya Katz to the red brick and beige stone house that Ms. Katz calls ''my little palace'' began more than half a century ago in the Ukrainian city of Mukachevo, near the Hungarian border. The Katzes, now both in their mid-50s, grew up on the same street, and knew each other as children. A particular bond was the
title: HABITATS; The House of Open Arms

body: HOW wrong can you go for $2.25? That's the price of a packet of 20 tomato seeds from Baker Creek Heirloom Seeds. The variety I'm considering is called Furry Yellow Hog, and the catalog copy suggests that it has citrus notes and a four o'clock shadow, two traits I have never associated with a tomato. Want to know more? That will not prove easy,
title: IN THE GARDEN; Packets Full of Miracles
